description: From Middle English recordour, borrowed from Old French recordour, from Old French recordeor, from Medieval Latin recordātor, from Latin recordor (“call to mind, remember, recollect”), from re- (“back, again”) + cor (“heart; mind”).

entries.meaning: An apparatus for recording; a device which records.
Agent noun of record; one who records.
A judge in a municipal court.

description: From Middle English recorder, from record (“to practice (music)”).

entries.meaning: (music) A musical instrument of the woodwind family; a type of fipple flute, a simple internal duct flute.
examples: Recorders are made in various sizes, from the high soprano or descant recorder to the low bass recorder.
